article.body: Workers prepare the stage for the first presidential debate between U.S. President Donald Trump and Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden in Cleveland, Ohio. Scott Olson/Getty Images The gloomy mixture of COVID-19 fears and political uncertainty are on investorsâ minds early on Tuesday. The global coronavirus death toll has now passed 1 million, according to Johns Hopkins University, which United Nations Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres described as âan agonizing milestone.â Many regions around the world are still reporting rising numbers of infections, also fueling fears over the impact of a second wave. Investors are anxiously awaiting the first presidential debate between President Donald Trump and Democratic challenger Joe Biden, which is expected to attract a record-breaking television audience from 9 p.m. Eastern time on Tuesday night. In our call of the day, Goldman Sachs GS, -0.21% strategists said they remained âpro-riskâ but warned risky assets may be stuck in a âfat and flat rangeâÂ unless election uncertainty eased.Â Markets have generally been ârisk offâ over the past week, they said, as COVID-19 cases rise and the likelihood of a vaccine by the first quarter of 2021 has diminished. âWhile we retain a fairly pro-risk stance in our asset allocation, volatility is likely to remain elevated in the near term â risk assets might continue to be stuck in a âfat and flatâ range,â the investment bankâs portfolio strategy research team wrote in a note late on Monday. The team said it would take more investor optimism around growth for stocks and other risky assets to breakout in a more sustained way. That would âlikely require falling uncertainty around the U.S. election and positive vaccine developments,â said the strategists, led by Christian Mueller-Glissmann. With the eyes of the world set to be on Trump and Biden later on Tuesday, the Goldman strategist said the first debate could be an âimportant catalyst for investors to assess risks.â Saxo Bank strategist Eleanor Creagh said, given Bidenâs lead in the polls, a strong showing in the debate could raise expectations of a Democratic clean sweep. âOne way to lower the odds of a contested outcome (that brings noise and volatility) is via a large margin of victory that cannot be undermined,â she said. âAlthough undoubtedly under the clean-sweep scenario there is the negative implications for risk assets to be considered, stemming from a Democratic legislative agenda including higher corporate taxes and increased capital-gains taxes,â Creagh added.The markets After climbing 410 points on Monday, the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, +0.56% was 0.6%, or 166 points lower in late morning trading. The S&P 500 SPX, +0.87% slipped 0.5% and the Nasdaq COMP, +1.39% was 0.2% down. European stocks also fell, as political uncertainty and fears of a second wave of the coronavirus pandemic concerned investors. The pan-European Stoxx 600 XX:SXXP was 0.3% lower in early trading, after enjoying its best one-day advance since June 22 on Monday. Asian markets were mixed overnight despite Wall Streetâs gains. The buzz Data-mining software company Palantir Technologies , and workplace collaboration and planning software provider Asana are expected to go public on Wednesday via the first direct listings of 2020, according to reports. French luxury goods giant LVMH MC, +1.15% countersued Tiffany & Co TIF, +0.37% on Monday, claiming the U.S. jeweler has been so badly damaged during the pandemic that the planned $16 billion takeover agreement is invalidated. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi agreed to keep talking on pandemic-related aid for the economy, even as House Democrats unveiled their own $2.2 trillion bill. Democratic vice-presidential nominee Kamala Harris said Trump and his Supreme Court nominee Amy Coney Barrett would overturn Obamacare, in a speech on Monday. United Airlines UAL, +0.32% said it has secured a deal to avoid furloughing pilots before next summer, reducing planned compulsory layoffs by about a quarter to under 12,000 â if more federal aid isnât forthcoming.
